basics.name: Caroline Mazini Rodrigues
basics.label: PhD student
basics.summary: Caroline is a PhD student of ESIEE Paris and EPITA being a member of the laboratories LIGM and LRE. She works with explicability of Deep Neural Networks.

work.name: Université Gustave Eiffel
work.position: Attaché temporaire d'enseignement et de recherche (ATER)

education.institution: Universidade Estadual Paulista Júlio de Mesquita Filho (UNESP)

awards.title: Academic Merit
awards.awarder: Faculdade de Ciência e Tecnologia – UNESP

publications.name: Unsupervised discovery of Interpretable Visual Concepts
publications.summary: In this paper, we propose two methods, Maximum Activation Groups Extraction (MAGE) and Multiscale Interpretable Visualization (Ms-IV), to explain the model's decision, enhancing global interpretability. MAGE finds, for a given CNN, combinations of features which, globally, form a semantic meaning, that we call concepts.

publications.name: Transforming gradient-based techniques into interpretable methods
publications.summary: We introduce GAD (Gradient Artificial Distancing) as a supportive framework for gradient-based explainable techniques. Its primary objective is to accentuate influential regions by establishing distinctions between classes. The essence of GAD is to limit the scope of analysis during visualization and, consequently reduce image noise.

publications.name: Bridging Human Concepts and Computer Vision for Explainable Face Verification
publications.summary: In this paper, we present an approach to combine computer and human vision to increase the explanation's interpretability of a face verification algorithm. In particular, we are inspired by the human perceptual process to understand how machines perceive face's human-semantic areas during face comparison tasks.

publications.name: Manifold Learning for Real-World Event Understanding
publications.summary: We extend upon our prior work and present a learning-from-data method for dynamically learning the contribution of different components for a more effective event representation. The method relies upon just a few training samples (few-shot learning), which can be easily provided by an investigator.

publications.name: Forensic Event Analysis: From Seemingly Unrelated Data to Understanding
publications.summary: We discuss the problem of restructuring visual data from different heterogeneous sources to analyze an event of interest. We present X-coherence: a pipeline seeking to organize and represent pieces of data, tying them coherently with the real world and with one another. We also outline research challenges while seeking X-coherence.

publications.name: Image Semantic Representation for Event Understanding
publications.summary: We propose an image semantic representation method that helps to understand the discrimination of Representative Images (RI) from Non-representative Images (NRI). Our method, called Event Semantic Space (ESS), generates a low-dimensional image representation by exploiting the semantics of some images with high representativeness and some representative components of the events (e.g., places, objects, and people).
